Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand how language varies as levels of formality and social distance change
Elaboration: Recognising language protocols for formal address, for example words used to address principals, heads of state and monarchs

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand how language varies as levels of formality and social distance change
Elaboration: Discussing levels of language such as slang, colloquial, conversational and formal, and how their appropriateness changes with the situation and audience

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand how language varies as levels of formality and social distance change
Elaboration: Presenting ideas and opinions at levels of formality appropriate for the context and audience

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand the uses of objective and subjective language, and identify bias
Elaboration: Identifying language choices that evoke emotion and judgements in direct and indirect ways, and how they are used to persuade different audiences to take a position and/or action

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand the uses of objective and subjective language, and identify bias
Elaboration: Understanding when to share feelings and opinions (for example, in a personal recount) and when to remain more objective (for example, in a factual recount)

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand the uses of objective and subjective language, and identify bias
Elaboration: Differentiating between reporting facts (for example, in a factual recount or unedited photograph) and providing a commentary (for example, in an editorial)

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Explain how different types of texts are typically organised into characteristic stages and phases depending on purposes, recognising how authors often adapt text structures and language features
Elaboration: Exploring a range of everyday, community, literary and informative texts, discussing elements of text structure and language features, and comparing the overall structure and effect of authors’ choices in 2 or more texts

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Explain how different types of texts are typically organised into characteristic stages and phases depending on purposes, recognising how authors often adapt text structures and language features
Elaboration: Examining a text to identify strategies such as exaggeration to create humour

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Explain how different types of texts are typically organised into characteristic stages and phases depending on purposes, recognising how authors often adapt text structures and language features
Elaboration: Recognising that texts are organised into stages, such as an introduction, and that introductions may be divided into phases; for example, the introduction stage of a narrative may begin with a phase that is a ‘hook’ or a flashback

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Explain how different types of texts are typically organised into characteristic stages and phases depending on purposes, recognising how authors often adapt text structures and language features
Elaboration: Explaining the characteristic stages and phases in reviews, discussing alternative positions or historical recounts, and identifying any adaptations of typical structures or language features

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand that sequence and cohesion can be created by the intentional use of repetition of text structures, language features and vocabulary
Elaboration: Noting how a general word is often used for a more specific word already mentioned (word association), for example ‘Look at those apples. Granny Smiths are my favourite.’

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand that sequence and cohesion can be created by the intentional use of repetition of text structures, language features and vocabulary
Elaboration: Recognising how cohesion can be developed through repeating key words or by using synonyms or antonyms

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand how embedded clauses can expand the variety of complex sentences to elaborate, extend and explain ideas
Elaboration: Investigating how the choice of conjunctions enables the construction of complex sentences to extend, elaborate on and explain ideas, for example ‘The town that was flooded suffered extensive damage.’

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand how embedded clauses can expand the variety of complex sentences to elaborate, extend and explain ideas
Elaboration: Creating complex sentences with embedded clauses to expand noun groups, for example ‘Hamish studied the rock samples that he had collected on the excursion, to complete his report.’

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand how the choice of verb, elaborated tenses and a range of adverb groups can expand and sharpen ideas
Elaboration: Knowing that the simple present tense is typically used to talk about present states (for example, ‘He lives in Darwin.’) or actions that happen regularly in the present (for example, ‘He watches television every night.’) or that represent ‘timeless’ happenings, such as in informative reports (for example, ‘Bears hibernate in winter.’)

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand how the choice of verb, elaborated tenses and a range of adverb groups can expand and sharpen ideas
Elaboration: Knowing that there are various ways in English to refer to future time, such as using the auxiliary ‘will’ (for example, ‘She will call you tomorrow.’), using the present tense (for example, ‘Tomorrow, I leave for Hobart.’) and using adverbials of time (for example, ‘She arrives in the morning.’)

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand how the choice of verb, elaborated tenses and a range of adverb groups can expand and sharpen ideas
Elaboration: Using precise verbs (for example, ‘slice’, ‘dice’, ‘fillet’ and ‘segment’) rather than general words (for example, ‘cut’)

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Identify the ways that still images (such as figures, tables, diagrams, maps and graphs), moving images and sound are used in texts to create point of view
Elaboration: Observing how sequential events can be represented visually by a series of images, including comic strips, timelines, photo stories, procedure diagrams and flow charts, life cycle diagrams and the flow of images in picture books

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Identify the ways that still images (such as figures, tables, diagrams, maps and graphs), moving images and sound are used in texts to create point of view
Elaboration: Observing how concepts, information and relationships can be represented visually through tables, maps, graphs and diagrams

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Identify the ways that still images (such as figures, tables, diagrams, maps and graphs), moving images and sound are used in texts to create point of view
Elaboration: Understanding that images and maps may be sensitive for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Peoples and ensuring that a disclaimer is applied or judgement is used about cultural appropriateness and sensitivities

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Examine how authors use vivid vocabulary and figurative language, such as metaphors, similes, personification, idioms, imagery and hyperbole
Elaboration: Exploring how figurative language (for example, metaphors, personification and idioms) can be used to create vivid and less predictable shades of meaning

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Examine how authors use vivid vocabulary and figurative language, such as metaphors, similes, personification, idioms, imagery and hyperbole
Elaboration: Identifying authors’ use of vivid and emotive vocabulary in persuasive texts, for example the vocabulary used in reviews

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Examine how authors use vivid vocabulary and figurative language, such as metaphors, similes, personification, idioms, imagery and hyperbole
Elaboration: Discussing texts, using vocabulary to name text structure, literary devices and language features; for example, using words that name the literary device used in a poem

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand how to use commas to separate a dependent clause from an independent clause
Elaboration: Identifying different uses of commas, such as commas and conjunctions between independent clauses in compound sentences

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Explore their responses to characters and events in literary texts drawn from historical, cultural or social contexts by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander authors and a wide range of Australian and world authors
Elaboration: Discussing the influence historical, cultural and social experiences may have on the meaning of a text and attitudes towards characters, actions and events

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Explore their responses to characters and events in literary texts drawn from historical, cultural or social contexts by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander authors and a wide range of Australian and world authors
Elaboration: Sharing responses about how heroes are portrayed in science fiction or fantasy and more realistic settings

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Explore their responses to characters and events in literary texts drawn from historical, cultural or social contexts by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander authors and a wide range of Australian and world authors
Elaboration: Exploring reviews of Australian films

Subject: English
Substrand: Engaging with and responding to literature
ContentDescription: Compare language choices, modality, emphasis, repetition and metaphor, and topics, themes or plots in a range of literary texts
Elaboration: Exploring texts on a similar topic by authors with very different styles; for example, comparing fantasy quest novels with realistic novels on a specific theme

Subject: English
Substrand: Engaging with and responding to literature
ContentDescription: Compare language choices, modality, emphasis, repetition and metaphor, and topics, themes or plots in a range of literary texts
Elaboration: Identifying differences in the use of narrator, narrative structure and voice, and language and visual features, between texts and determining how these influence readers or viewers

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Describe characteristics of literary texts that define an author’s individual style
Elaboration: Exploring 2 or more texts by the same author, identifying similarities (for example, subject or theme, characterisation, text structure, plot development, tone, vocabulary, voice, favoured grammatical structures and visual techniques in picture books) and describing the qualities that characterise an author’s style

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Describe characteristics of literary texts that define an author’s individual style
Elaboration: Focusing on an Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander author and identifying characteristic elements of their writing, for example imagery, theme and language

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Explain the way authors use sound and imagery to create meaning and effect in prose and poetry
Elaboration: Explaining how imagery builds emotional connections and engagement with the story or theme

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Explain the way authors use sound and imagery to create meaning and effect in prose and poetry
Elaboration: Identifying the imagery used in narratives or poetry about Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Peoples’ Country/Place

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Explain the way authors use sound and imagery to create meaning and effect in prose and poetry
Elaboration: Describing the effects of assonance, alliteration and onomatopoeia in a poem

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Explain the way authors use sound and imagery to create meaning and effect in prose and poetry
Elaboration: Explaining the effect of rhythm in ballads

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Create texts that adapt plot structure, characters, settings and/or ideas from literary texts they have encountered, and experiment with vocabulary and literary devices
Elaboration: Creating narratives in written, spoken, multimodal or digital form by adapting character; for example, reimagining the hero in an adventure story

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Create texts that adapt plot structure, characters, settings and/or ideas from literary texts they have encountered, and experiment with vocabulary and literary devices
Elaboration: Creating an autobiography of a character from a text they have explored

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use interaction skills and awareness of formality when paraphrasing, questioning, clarifying and interrogating ideas; developing and supporting arguments; and sharing and evaluating information, experiences and opinions
Elaboration: Participating in pair, group, class, school and community speaking and listening situations, including informal conversations, discussions, debates and presentations

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use interaction skills and awareness of formality when paraphrasing, questioning, clarifying and interrogating ideas; developing and supporting arguments; and sharing and evaluating information, experiences and opinions
Elaboration: Using strategies (for example, pausing, questioning, rephrasing, repeating, summarising, reviewing and asking clarifying questions) when discussing topics

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use interaction skills and awareness of formality when paraphrasing, questioning, clarifying and interrogating ideas; developing and supporting arguments; and sharing and evaluating information, experiences and opinions
Elaboration: Recognising that closed questions ask for precise responses, while open questions prompt a speaker to provide more information

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Deliver structured spoken and multimodal texts to an intended audience for a specific purpose, using appropriate features of voice
Elaboration: Experimenting with voice effects such as tone, volume, pitch and pace in formal presentations and recognising the effects these have on audience understanding

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Deliver structured spoken and multimodal texts to an intended audience for a specific purpose, using appropriate features of voice
Elaboration: Presenting an argument about an issue from learning area content, which includes claims supported with evidence and examples, careful use of topic-specific vocabulary and selection of persuasive techniques appropriate for audience

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Deliver structured spoken and multimodal texts to an intended audience for a specific purpose, using appropriate features of voice
Elaboration: Setting goals for a presentation and monitoring development in a written or digital journal

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use combined phonological, morphological and vocabulary knowledge to read and write increasingly complex words
Elaboration: Using phonic generalisations to read and write complex words with uncommon letter patterns, for example ‘pneumonia’, ‘resuscitate’ and ‘vegetation’

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use their knowledge of known words, base words, prefixes, suffixes, letter patterns, spelling generalisations and word origins (etymology), including some Latin and Greek roots, to spell new words, including technical words
Elaboration: Using a dictionary to explore word origins, including some Greek roots, in order to spell words; for example, the Greek root ‘ath’ meaning ‘contest’ or ‘outstanding skill’, ‘pent’ meaning the number 5 and ‘dec’ meaning the number 10 inform the spelling and meaning of the words ‘athlete’, ‘pentathlon’ and ‘decathlon’

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use their knowledge of known words, base words, prefixes, suffixes, letter patterns, spelling generalisations and word origins (etymology), including some Latin and Greek roots, to spell new words, including technical words
Elaboration: Applying accumulated knowledge of a wide range of letter patterns and spelling generalisations to spell new words, for example ‘ratio’ and ‘synthesis’

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use their knowledge of known words, base words, prefixes, suffixes, letter patterns, spelling generalisations and word origins (etymology), including some Latin and Greek roots, to spell new words, including technical words
Elaboration: Expanding knowledge of prefixes and suffixes, and exploring meaning relationships between words, for example ‘disappearance’, ‘submarine’, ‘subterranean’, ‘poisonous’ and ‘nervous’

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use their knowledge of known words, base words, prefixes, suffixes, letter patterns, spelling generalisations and word origins (etymology), including some Latin and Greek roots, to spell new words, including technical words
Elaboration: Applying accumulated knowledge of a wide range of letter patterns and spelling generalisations to spell new words; for example, knowing how and why these words are spelt as follows: ‘reliability’, ‘handkerchief’, ‘receive’, ‘lollies’, ‘trolleys’, ‘climbing’, ‘designed’ and ‘emergency’

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use their knowledge of known words, base words, prefixes, suffixes, letter patterns, spelling generalisations and word origins (etymology), including some Latin and Greek roots, to spell new words, including technical words
Elaboration: Spelling technical words by applying morphemic knowledge, for example ‘metaphorical’, ‘biology’ and ‘biodegradable’

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Select and read different types of texts of varying complexity, integrating phonic, semantic and grammatical knowledge to read accurately and fluently for meaning, re-reading and self-correcting when needed
Elaboration: Bringing subject and technical vocabulary and concept knowledge to new reading tasks, and selecting, evaluating and using texts for their pertinence to the task and the accuracy of their information

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Select and read different types of texts of varying complexity, integrating phonic, semantic and grammatical knowledge to read accurately and fluently for meaning, re-reading and self-correcting when needed
Elaboration: Using their knowledge of text structure to navigate the text to locate specific content for a purpose

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Examine texts, including media texts, that represent ideas and events, and identify how they reflect the context in which they were created
Elaboration: Identifying news reports of the same type of event over time and how they reflect their contexts

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Examine texts, including media texts, that represent ideas and events, and identify how they reflect the context in which they were created
Elaboration: Comparing advertising posters for animated children’s films in different countries and explaining the impact of these choices on audience expectations of the film

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Examine texts, including media texts, that represent ideas and events, and identify how they reflect the context in which they were created
Elaboration: Identifying how advertisements for the same products reflect the context in which they were created

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Analyse how text structures and language features work together to meet the purpose of a text and engage and influence audiences
Elaboration: Comparing the structure and language features of different texts, including print and digital sources on similar topics, and evaluating which features best aid navigation and clear communication about the topic

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use comprehension strategies, such as visualising, predicting, connecting, summarising, monitoring and questioning, and connect and compare ideas from a variety of sources to build literal and inferred meanings
Elaboration: Making connections between the text and their own experiences or other texts

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use comprehension strategies, such as visualising, predicting, connecting, summarising, monitoring and questioning, and connect and compare ideas from a variety of sources to build literal and inferred meanings
Elaboration: Making connections between information in print and images

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use comprehension strategies, such as visualising, predicting, connecting, summarising, monitoring and questioning, and connect and compare ideas from a variety of sources to build literal and inferred meanings
Elaboration: Using prior knowledge and textual information to make inferences

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use comprehension strategies, such as visualising, predicting, connecting, summarising, monitoring and questioning, and connect and compare ideas from a variety of sources to build literal and inferred meanings
Elaboration: Asking and answering questions

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use comprehension strategies, such as visualising, predicting, connecting, summarising, monitoring and questioning, and connect and compare ideas from a variety of sources to build literal and inferred meanings
Elaboration: Using graphic organisers to visualise connections, categories and hierarchies of information

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use comprehension strategies, such as visualising, predicting, connecting, summarising, monitoring and questioning, and connect and compare ideas from a variety of sources to build literal and inferred meanings
Elaboration: Summarising a text or part of a text

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Create different types of texts, written and spoken, with developed and organised ideas for purpose and audience, and multimodal elements as appropriate
Elaboration: Planning a report on a topic, sequencing ideas logically and providing supporting detail (including graphics, sound and visuals) to enhance audience engagement and understanding

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Create different types of texts, written and spoken, with developed and organised ideas for purpose and audience, and multimodal elements as appropriate
Elaboration: Creating informative texts for 2 different audiences that explore a topic using text structure and language features for the identified audiences, noting the changes required to appeal to each audience

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Create different types of texts, written and spoken, with developed and organised ideas for purpose and audience, and multimodal elements as appropriate
Elaboration: Using rhetorical devices, images and modal verbs for persuasive effects, for an identified audience

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Create different types of texts, written and spoken, with developed and organised ideas for purpose and audience, and multimodal elements as appropriate
Elaboration: Selecting and combining digital tools to create texts

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Re-read and edit their own texts and the texts of others using agreed criteria and exploring editing choices
Elaboration: Discussing the setting in a literary text with a peer during the editing process, and experimenting with literary devices that may enhance the setting

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Re-read and edit their own texts and the texts of others using agreed criteria and exploring editing choices
Elaboration: Re-reading and editing their own and others’ work using negotiated criteria for text structure, meaning and accuracy of grammar, spelling and punctuation, and explaining editing choices as required

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Write legibly, fluently and automatically for sustained periods
Elaboration: Content description does not require elaboration.
